Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2010 03:43AM Leslie1962 wrote: I had a 3.5 cm tumor and 13/18 positive nodes that pushed me to a IIIC. Prior to the thickening, which I found two weeks after a clean annual GYN appointment, I had clear mammograms. No family history. MRI and US barely saw the area of concern and I was told to come back in six months. Even got a letter from the hospital stating I did not have cancer - go figure. I demanded to have a biopsy which then showed the cancer. Very disappointed that I did everything I was supposed to do and docs were not more aggressive when it came to my dense breast tissue. I feel if I had known about dense tissue a few years ago I would have been more aggressive with my doctor to push for additional testing. Now here I am, stage IIIC.
Posts.Title: Tumor Size in Stage III peverson Leslie1962

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2009 02:02PM Leslie1962 wrote: I also had a very hard lump appear out of the blue within two weeks of a normal annual check-up. Mammogram and ultrasound were negative. I pushed for a biopsy and what came back was invasive breast cancer. In my opinion you should not wait. My doctor/s also wanted to wait for six months even with a pathology report (from needle aspiration) stating "atypical cells" and the hard lump that was not going away and I found that to be unacceptable. Be your own advocate and push for the testing. Sorry, don't want to scare you but you do need to know what is going on.

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2011 02:37PM Leslie1962 wrote: I had the same chemo PLUS taxol and taxotere as well as herceptin. I think its the steroids. About the third or fourth day after infusion I got a very flushed red face due to the steroids. I didn't sleep well at all during that time either. Neulasta shot was tough. I got terrible bone pain about 4-5 days after the shot. But it does all go away, just in time for the next infusion. As others have said, ask your doctor if you continue to be bothered by the side-effects.

Posts.Title: DD Taxol and Neuropathy, quit early? her2intn LouLou40

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2011 10:27AM - edited Feb 18, 2011 10:27AM by Leslie1962 I had/have almost the exact symptoms you are complaining about. I made it through 6/12 taxol and herceptin before I had to quit the taxol. My doctor then switched me to taxotere, which is in the same family, but not known for the numbness and tingling. My last chemo (taxotere) was April 20, 2010. Not to put a damper on things, but my feet have never been the same. I hope you have better luck than I have. After all these months I still have problems with my feet and it just infuriates me that it limits what I can do on some days. My nurse practitioner said that once you stop taxol you should see improvement between 6-16 months after your last dose if you are going to have improvement at all. I am now 10 months out and have just gotten a prescription from my doctor to try gabapentin for the neuropathy. I will get it filled today and hope to see improvement. Good luck! Talk to your doctor about Gabapentin/Neurontin. He/she may be willing to let you try it to see if you have any benefit from it.

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2009 08:49PM Leslie1962 wrote: Here is my story regarding my lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy. I underwent lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy on September 23, 2009. I did have pain at the lumpectomy site for at least a good three weeks (just from the healing process) and the incision under the arm has been a hassel. Since the node biopsy I have not had much feeling under my arm. I ended up having fluid accumulate in the breast cavity (which is not at all unusual) and had to have it drained twice in the last month. A couple of days after the surgery every time I got up I could hear fluid moving around. If this happens, just let your doctor know. Once I had the fluid drained most of the discomfort went away. I took prescribed pain medication for only two days and was up and about in no time. I went home a few hours after the surgery and went back to work in three weeks. Good luck tomorrow. I hope this provides some insight into what you may/may not expect.

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2009 08:21PM Leslie1962 wrote: First off, slow down and take a breath! This is all too much information for you to process clearly at the moment, and at this time of year as well. I have much the same diagnosis, check the info at the bottom of this reply. Sounds like you are in good hands and things are moving along quickly. Be sure to ask many questions. Talk to your kids. Mine are 15 and 16 and totally freaked out when we told them. But once all their questions began to be answered and they saw I was still here doing everything I had always done, things got much easier. Yes, they are still concerned but that is to be expected and quite honestly normal. Hope things get better for you soon. Take care.
